document.docAuthor: Pádua, Diego G., Sääksjärvi, Ilari E., Monteiro, Ricardo F. & Oliveira, Marcio L.
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the New World genus Acrotaphus Townes, 1960 (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae: Pimplinae), with descriptions of fifteen new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the New World genus Acrotaphus Townes, 1960 (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae: Pimplinae), with descriptions of fifteen new species

bibRefCitation.author: Gauld, I. D.
bibRefCitation.refString: Gauld, I. D. (1991) The Ichneumonidae of Costa Rica I. Memoirs of the American Entomological Institute, 47, 1 - 589.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Acrotaphus franklini
Gauld, 1991: 329
. Holotype ♀ , Costa Rica (MNCR) [examined by digital image]

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species can be distinguished from all other species of
Acrotaphus
by the combination of the following characters: 1) margin of gena behind eyes flat in dorsal view; 2) margin of gena 0.6–0.7× length of eye in dorsal view; 3) posterior ocelli separated from eyes by 0.4–0.7× its diameter in dorsal view; 4) mesosoma black, except scutellum orange or mesosoma orange with propleuron, pronotum, mesoscutum and anterior and ventral region of mesopleuron black; 5) metasoma orange, with tergites V+ black; 6) ovipositor robust, 1.3–1.6× as long as hind tibia.
Distribution. Brazil *, Colombia **, Costa Rica , Ecuador ** and Peru * ( Fig 91 ).

Biological notes. One male was collected from the nest of the
Trypoxylon ( Trypargilum ) lactitarse Saussure, 1867
( Crabronidae ). This record is similar to the strange case documented by Palacio (1999), who found a species of the
Acrotaphus
from the nest of the
Trigonopsis violascens (Dalla Torre, 1897)
( Sphecidae ). Palacio (1991) suggested this was an accidental case, where the solitary wasp captures and imprisons an already parasitized spider (with egg/larva of the
Acrotaphus
). This is the first record of the genus
Acrotaphus
in nest of Crabronidae .

.
